text: Johnny Flamingo, born Melvin James Moore (January 13, 1934 – December 24, 2000) was an American rhythm and blues singer and lyricist. ==Biography== He was born in Houston, Texas, the son of Grant Moore and Gladys Gilmore, and grew up as Melvin Broxton after taking the name of his stepfather. He joined the US Air Force and served in Europe where he performed as a member of a vocal group, the Five Criterions. In 1956 he returned to Los Angeles, where radio DJ Dick "Huggy Boy" Hugg reportedly gave him the stage name Johnny Flamingo. Anthony Randall, "Looking for Johnny Flamingo", The Guardian, 14 November 2004. Retrieved October 18, 2017 He joined a vocal doo-wop group, the Dots, formed by singer Jeanette Baker, and became their lead tenor on recordings on Hugg's Caddy label, including "I Confess", a song covered by Paul Anka as his first record. "The Dots", Doo-Wop Groups. Retrieved October 18, 2017 Flamingo and Baker married, and Flamingo left the group in 1957 for a solo career. He released a series of singles in the late 1950s and early 1960s, on various labels including Caddy, Aladdin, and Specialty. He also recorded and performed with his wife, Jeanette Baker, and performed regularly at a club, the Den, in Norwalk, California. Flamingo sang rock and roll as well as ballad songs in the style of Nat King Cole. In 1959 he released an LP, Johnny Flamingo Sings in the Wee Small Hours, featuring Gaynel Hodge on piano, released on the Diadon label owned by Joe Serrano."Johnny Flamingo", Colorradio.com. Retrieved October 17, 2017 Flamingo is also credited as the lyricist on some versions of the originally instrumental hits "Wheels" and "Apache". Johnny Flamingo, Writing and arrangement credits. Retrieved October 18, 2017 Johnny Flamingo died in Los Angeles in 2000, from cancer and emphysema. Jeanette Baker biography, MissJeanetteBaker.com.
